DOC.HEAD: Army MPs, Working With Panamanians, Could Be in for Long Stay
Eds: CORRECTS 11th graf, American MPs, to insert dropped word ``unlike'' in quote
DOC.TEXT: With Panama in chaos, U.S. officials said Friday that military police trained to restore and enforce law and order will play a large role in the country, possibly staying as long as a year. Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of the U.S. Southern Command, told reporters at a new conference in Panama that a top U.S. priority was to ``raise the (Panamanian) police force and get it back in operation.'' In Washington, Gen. Tom Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, stressed the importance of the military police. ``The role we will play is assisting the Panamanians ... in maintaining order and recapturing and controlling of their institutions like the police,'' he said. ``We've got to re-establish law and order throughout Panama City,'' said Lt. Col. Bill Bennett, a top military planner. Military experts said the military police might work with Panamanian Defense Forces loyal to new President Guillermo Endara, training them and incorporating them on patrols. U.S. officials spoke while mobs, some devoted to ousted Gen. Manuel Noriega, roamed Panama City, ``breaking windows, entering private homes, looting at will,'' according to Jan Edmonson, the U.S. Embassy spokesman in Panama City. By Friday _ the third day of the U.S. intervention _ the military police numbered 3,000, Bennett said. Some 1,500 reinforcements from Fort Bragg, N.C., were brought in to help. All told, U.S. troops number about 24,000. U.S. military officials refused to say how long they would keep combat troops in Panama, but Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, predicted the military police might be in for a long haul. ``I would not be surprised to see them there on Christmas Eve a year from now,'' he said. Military police _ or MPs _ have a number of specific tasks, including security and law enforcement at U.S. bases, the support of combat forces and protection of prisoners of war. In Panama, some 1,400 pro-Noriega loyalists are being held prisoner, Thurman said. American MPs ``are not too much unlike a civilian police force,'' said Michael Abrams, a spokesman at Fort McClellan near Anniston, Ala., home of the U.S. Army Military Police School. MPs were recently in the headlines when they were sent to the Virgin Islands to restore calm after Hurricane Hugo. But Abrams said the situation in the Virgin Islands differed substantially from that in Panama. In the islands, MPs worked in concert with local law enforcement officers, letting the civil authorities play the lead role in making arrests and controlling disorderly conduct. But in Panama, ``it seems like the whole country has been turned upside down,'' he said. ``I haven't the faintest idea how they are operate.'' Richard Armitage, a former Defense Department official, suggested the new government in Panama temporarily might empower the MPs with authority to make arrests and handle other problems. MPs, often the most visible servicemen because of their public function, are trained to handle scores of tasks from criminal investigations to traffic. On bases, they commonly patrol housing areas, set up speed traps and make arrests. They also protect convoys, set up perimeter security and quell disturbances.
